å°æ°éè·¯ç¬¬äºåçº¿ | color = | logo = | logo_width = | logo_alt = | image = Lanxin High-Speed Railway.PNG | image_width = 240px | image_alt = | caption = | type = [[High-speed rail]] | system = | status = Under construction | locale = [[People's Republic of China|China]] | start = [[Lanzhou]] | end = [[Urumqi]] | stations = 31 | routes = | ridership = | ridership2 = | open = December 2013 | close = | owner = | operator = [[China Railway High-speed]] | character = | depot = | stock = | linelength = {{convert|1776|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} | tracklength = | notrack = | gauge = {{RailGauge|sg|al=on}} | old gauge = | lgauge = | minradius = 7,000 meters | maxincline = 20â° | racksystem = | route number= | el = | speed = {{convert|350|km/h|mph|0|abbr=on}} | elevation = | website = | map = {{LanzhouâUrumqi High-Speed Railway/route map}} | map_state = show }} The '''LanzhouâUrumqi High-Speed Railway''', also known as '''Lanxin Second Railway''', is a [[high-speed rail]] under construction in [[Northwest China|northwestern]] [[China]]. It will connect [[Lanzhou]] in [[Gansu|Gansu Province]] and [[ÃrÃ¼mqi]] in [[Xinjiang|Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region]]. Construction work began on November 4, 2009. The {{convert|1776|km|adj=on}} railway will take four years to complete, of which, {{convert|795|km}} is in [[Gansu]], {{convert|268|km}} in [[Qinghai]] and {{convert|713|km}} in [[Xinjiang]]. 31 [[train station|stations]] will be built along the line. The project costs 143.5 billion yuan.{{cite news|url=http://politics.people.com.cn/GB/14562/10317457.html|title=å°æ°éè·¯ç¬¬äºåçº¿ä»æ¥å¨ä¹é²æ¨é½å¼å·¥|language=Chinese|date=November 4, 2009|accessdate=November 6, 2009}} Upon its completion, an overnight sleeper train is expected to connect Beijing to Urumqi, 3,450 km apart, in less than 12 hours.http://cq.qq.com/a/20091105/000648.htm Unlike the existing [[Lanxin railway]], which runs entirely in Gansu and Xinjiang, the new high-speed rail will be routed from Lanzhou to [[Qinghai|Qinghai Province]] to [[Xining]] before heading northwest across the [[Qilian Mountains]] into the [[Hexi Corridor]] at [[Zhangye]]. The rail tracks in the section near Qilianshan Tunnel will be at 3,858 meters above sea levelhttp://www.chinadaily.com.cn/dfpd/gansu/2010-10-01/content_954064.html, making it the highest high-speed rail track in the world. Trains will run at 350 kilometres per hour on the line.[http://news.163.com/10/0220/14/5VVMOUR2000120GU.html å°æ°éè·¯ç¬¬äºåçº¿æ°çæ®µæ¥èæ½å·¥ç­ç«æå¤©]http://www.tianshannet.com.cn/news/content/2010-12/12/content_5436119.htm == Wind shed == {{seealso|List of wind-related railway accidents}} Near [[Shanshan]], the railway will go through the ''hundred-[[Li (length)|li]] wind zone'', where desert wind constantly blows most days of a year. In 2007, strong wind overturned a train on the southern branch of Lanxin Railway, and four people were killed.[http://www.china.org.cn/english/China/200975.htm Strong Wind Derails Train, Killing 4] A 67-kilometre long wind-protection gallery will be built in this region. == References == {{reflist}} {{High-speed rail in the People's Republic of China}} {{coord missing|China}} [[Category:High-speed railway lines in the People's Republic of China]] [[Category:Rail transport in Gansu]] [[Category:Rail transport in Qinghai]] [[Category:Rail transport in Xinjiang]] [[Category:Standard gauge railways in the People's Republic of China]] [[hu:LancsouâÃrÃ¼mcsi nagysebessÃ©gÅ± vasÃºtvonal]] [[zh:å°æ°éè·¯ç¬¬äºåçº¿]]
